thread.title: Delay, not death, tipped for Qld coalmine
thread.title_full: Delay, not death, tipped for Qld coalmine

title: Delay, not death, tipped for Qld coalmine
text:
View Photo 

A recent legal roadblock won't quash Indian mining giant Adani's plans for a giant coalmine in central Queensland, the state government says. 
Conservationists claimed a win after the Federal Court on Monday ordered the $16.5 billion Carmichael mine's approval be set aside, when a legal loophole in Environment Minister Greg Hunt's decision was discovered. 
They say he failed to consider two threatened species - the yakka skink and ornamental snake. 
But the minister rejected the suggestion he'd made a bureaucratic or personal bungle and says a fresh decision will be made in six to eight weeks. 
And there's "every likelihood" he will approve it again, state Treasurer Curtis Pitt said. 
"We think this is a delay, not anything more than that," he said on Thursday. 
Deputy Premier Jackie Trad echoed his sentiments, assuring a business lunch in Brisbane the state's reputation as a mining and resource hub hadn't been scotched. 
However, she conceded it would be important for Queensland to broaden its economic base to guard against an over-reliance on mining. 
The royalties generated by the project were a crucial source of funding for hospitals, schools and roads, opposition leader Lawrence Springborg said. 
For its part, Adani is apparently undeterred at having to wait for a new approval. 
Federal Queensland MP George Christensen, whose Dawson electorate is in the vicinity of the proposed mine, said the company was interested in "sticking it out". 
They intended to simply re-jig their project timeline when the new decision is made, he said. 
But doubts about its future are still swirling, with the Commonwealth Bank's financial advice mandate with Adani ending on Wednesday. 
Ms Trad admitted it was a blow for the mine but Adani would continue having discussions with State Planning Minister Anthony Lynham. 
Meanwhile, environmental and advocacy lobbies welcomed the bank's decision as a sign the project's viability was waning. 
Ultimately it's all about making sure government and companies are properly scrutinised, Jo-Anne Bragg from Queensland's Environmental Defenders Office said. 
She said EDO Qld has written to Mr Hunt citing extra information about Adani's environmental reputation and the economic benefit of the project to Australia. @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Delay, not death, tipped for Qld coalmine AAP
